waste_types.name: Organic Waste
waste_types.description: This waste type includes food scraps, yard waste, and other natural materials. It can be composted to decompose naturally and turn into nutrient-rich soil.

waste_types.name: Paper and Cardboard
waste_types.description: Paper and cardboard waste are biodegradable materials made from plant fibers. They can decompose naturally when exposed to moisture and microorganisms.

waste_types.name: Textiles
waste_types.description: Textiles, like old clothing and fabrics, are biodegradable. While they may take longer to decompose than food waste, they will eventually break down naturally.

waste_types.name: Wood
waste_types.description: Wood waste is biodegradable and can decompose naturally over time.

waste_types.name: Electronics
waste_types.description: This waste consists of electronic devices like computers, smartphones, and appliances. It should be taken to specialized e-waste recycling centers to ensure proper disposal and recovery of valuable materials.

waste_types.name: Glass
waste_types.description: Glass waste should be separated by color (clear, green, brown) and recycled at recycling centers. It can be reused to create new glass products.

waste_types.name: Medical
waste_types.description: This type of waste includes items like syringes, gloves, and other medical equipment. It requires careful handling and should be disposed of following strict guidelines to prevent potential health hazards.

waste_types.name: Metal
waste_types.description: Metal waste, such as cans and scrap metal, can be recycled at recycling facilities to conserve resources and reduce environmental impact.

waste_types.name: Plastic
waste_types.description: Plastic waste should be separated by type (PET, HDPE, etc.) and recycled at appropriate recycling facilities. Some types may not be recyclable, so reducing plastic consumption is also essential.
